options.feedback:
✗ Oops! Too fast to capture light trails.
A shutter speed like 1/2000s is extremely fast — it would freeze any motion completely. You would see distinct car shapes or headlights, not long continuous light streaks.

✗ Oops! Still too fast for light trails.
While 1/60s is slower than 1/2000s, it's still not long enough to create smooth, extended light trails. You might get a bit of blur, but not the dramatic streaks seen in the photo.

✔ Correct!
A shutter speed of 2 seconds allows the camera to capture moving car lights over time, resulting in continuous light trails. This is a common technique in night photography.
✗ Oops! ISO 3200 adds visible noise and 1/30 s is shaky hand-held, even though f/2.0 is bright.
✔ Correct! ISO 100 keeps the image clean, f/1.8 gives creamy bokeh, and 1/250 s freezes a portrait.
✗ Not quite... f/5.6 produces deep depth-of-field so the background stays sharp; ISO 800 also raises noise unnecessarily.

✔ Correct! A narrow f/11 aperture keeps everything sharp, and bright daylight lets you stay at ISO 100. This setting uses a low ISO for maximum image quality, a narrow aperture (f/11) to keep the entire landscape in sharp focus (deep depth of field), and a moderately fast shutter speed (1/250s) to avoid motion blur — ideal for bright outdoor scenes.
✗ Not quite... ISO 800 lowers image quality, f/4.0 won’t give edge-to-edge sharpness, and 1/1000 s wastes light.
✗ Oops! Better, but f/5.6 is still too wide for maximum depth-of-field; some of the scene may be soft.
✗ Not quite... A 2-second exposure is impossible to hand-hold and f/11 lets in very little light.

✔ Correct! High ISO plus a wide aperture gathers enough light, and 1/30 s is just hand-holdable. In low-light conditions, this combination provides a high ISO to brighten the image, a wide aperture (f/2.0) to gather more light, and a shutter speed (1/30s) that's just fast enough for handheld shooting without blur — making it the most practical choice at night.
✗ Oops! 1/2 s will blur a busy street and f/5.6 is too narrow; ISO 800 is still too low for night scenes.
